Body: Another example of this might be the recent acquisition of rather good English by large numbers of people in Scandinavia. In the case in Iceland, initially Danish was taught at schools, but that didn't lead to widespread Danish fluency (at least not to the degree you see English fluency now). After independence they switched to English as the most important second language, with much the same sort of schooling and contact with foreigners (i.e. not much), there is widespread English fluency in Iceland. I suppose some of that could be attributed to children hearing English in mass media.
